He later studied and worked alongside Georges Seurat and Paul Signac when he took on the Neo-Imp

heading: Births
txt: Alvan Graham Clark, American astronomer (d. 1897)

entities.title: Alvan Graham Clark
entities.description: Alvan Graham Clark was an American astronomer and telescope-maker.

heading: Births
txt: Henryk Wieniawski, Polish violinist and composer (d. 1880)

entities.title: Henryk Wieniawski
entities.description: Henryk Wieniawski was a Polish virtuoso violinist, composer and pedagogue who is regarded amongst the greatest violinists in history. His younger brother Józef Wieniawski and nephew Adam Tadeusz Wieniawski were also accomplished musicians.

heading: Births
txt: Adolphus Busch, German brewer, co-founded Anheuser-Busch (d. 1913)

entities.title: Adolphus Busch
entities.description: Adolphus Busch was the Hessian co-founder of Anheuser-Busch with his father-in-law, Eberhard Anheuser. He introduced numerous innovations, building the success of the company in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. He became a philanthropist, using some of his wealth for education and humanitarian needs. His great-great-grandson, August Busch IV, is a former CEO of Anheuser-Busch InBev.

entities.title: Anheuser-Busch
entities.description: Anheuser-Busch Companies, LLC is an American brewing company headquartered in St. Louis, Missouri. Since 2008, it has been a wholly owned subsidiary of Anheuser-Busch InBev which also has its North American regional management headquarters in St. Louis.

heading: Births
txt: Nikola Tesla, Serbian-American physicist and engineer (d. 1943)

entities.title: Nikola Tesla
entities.description: Nikola Tesla was a Serbian-American inventor, electrical engineer, mechanical engineer, and futurist best known for his contributions to the design of the modern alternating current (AC) electricity supply system.

heading: Births
txt: Austin Chapman, Australian businessman and politician, 4th Australian Minister for Defence (d. 1926)

entities.title: Austin Chapman
entities.description: Sir Austin Chapman was an Australian politician who served in the House of Representatives from 1901 until his death in 1926. He held ministerial office in the governments of Alfred Deakin and Stanley Bruce, serving as Minister for Defence (1903–1904), Postmaster-General (1905–1907), Minister for Trade and Customs, and Minister for Health (1923–1924).

entities.title: Minister for Defence (Australia)
entities.description: The Minister for Defence is the principal minister responsible for the organisation, implementation, and formulation of government policy in defence and military matters for the Australian Government. The individual who holds this office directs the government’s approach to such matters through the Australian Defence Organisation and, by extension, the Department of Defence and the Australian Defe

heading: Births
txt: Prince Maximilian of Baden (d. 1929)

entities.title: Prince Maximilian of Baden
entities.description: Maximilian, Margrave of Baden, also known as Max von Baden, was a German prince, general, and politician. He was heir presumptive to the throne of the Grand Duchy of Baden, and in October and November 1918 briefly served as Chancellor of the German Empire. He sued for peace on Germany's behalf at the end of World War I based on U.S. President Woodrow Wilson's Fourteen Points, which included immedi

heading: Births
txt: Marcel Proust, French novelist, critic, and essayist (d. 1922)

entities.title: Marcel Proust
entities.description: Valentin Louis Georges Eugène Marcel Proust was a French novelist, critic, and essayist who wrote the monumental novel À la recherche du temps perdu, published in seven parts between 1913 and 1927. He is considered by critics and writers to be one of the most influential authors of the 20th century.

heading: Births
txt: Sergey Konenkov, Russian sculptor (d. 1971)

entities.title: Sergey Konenkov
entities.description: Sergey Timofeyevich Konenkov  was a famous Russian and Soviet sculptor. He was often called "the Russian Rodin".

heading: Births
txt: Mary McLeod Bethune, American educator and activist (d. 1955)

entities.title: Mary McLeod Bethune
entities.description: Mary Jane McLeod Bethune was an American educator, stateswoman, philanthropist, humanitarian, womanist, and civil rights activist. Bethune founded the National Council for Negro Women in 1935, established the organization's flagship journal Aframerican Women's Journal, and resided as president or leader for myriad African American women's organizations including the National Association for Colore

heading: Births
txt: Dezső Pattantyús-Ábrahám, Hungarian politician (d. 1973)

heading: Births
txt: Ernst Bresslau, German zoologist (d. 1935)

entities.title: Ernst Bresslau
entities.description: Ernst Ludwig Bresslau was a German zoologist. He was the son of historian Harry Bresslau.

heading: Births
txt: Otto Freundlich, German painter and sculptor (d. 1943)

entities.title: Otto Freundlich
entities.description: Otto Freundlich was a German painter and sculptor of Jewish origin. A part of the first generation of abstract painters in Western art, Freundlich was a great admirer of cubism.

heading: Births
txt: Ima Hogg, American society leader, philanthropist, patron and collector of the arts (d. 1975)

entities.title: Ima Hogg
entities.description: Ima Hogg, known as "The First Lady of Texas", was an American society leader, philanthropist, patron and collector of the arts, and one of the most respected women in Texas during the 20th century. Hogg was an avid art collector, and owned works by Picasso, Klee, and Matisse, among others. Hogg donated hundreds of pieces of artwork to Houston's Museum of Fine Arts and served on a committee to plan

heading: Births
txt: Johannes Blaskowitz, German general (d. 1948)

entities.title: Johannes Blaskowitz
entities.description: Johannes Albrecht Blaskowitz was a German general during World War II and recipient of the Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross with Oak Leaves and Swords.

heading: Births
txt: Hugo Raudsepp, Estonian playwright and politician (d. 1952)

heading: Births
txt: Giorgio de Chirico, Greek-Italian painter and set designer (d. 1978)

entities.title: Giorgio de Chirico
entities.description: Giorgio de Chirico was an Italian artist and writer born in Greece. In the years before World War I, he founded the scuola metafisica art movement, which profoundly influenced the surrealists. His most well-known works often feature Roman arcades, long shadows, mannequins, trains, and illogical perspective. His imagery reflects his affinity for the philosophy of Arthur Schopenhauer and of Friedric

heading: Births
txt: Toyohiko Kagawa, Japanese evangelist, author, and activist (d. 1960)

heading: Births
txt: Edith Quimby, American medical researcher and physicist (d. 1982)

entities.title: Edith Quimby
entities.description: Edith Hinkley Quimby was an American medical researcher and physicist, best known as one of the founders of nuclear medicine. Her work involved developing diagnostic and therapeutic applications of X-rays. One of her main concerns was protecting both those handling the radioactive material and making sure that those being treated were given the lowest dose necessary.

heading: Births
txt: Jimmy McHugh, American composer (d. 1969)

entities.title: Jimmy McHugh
entities.description: James Francis McHugh was an American composer. One of the most prolific songwriters from the 1920s to the 1950s, he is credited with over 500 songs. His songs were recorded by many artists, including Chet Baker, June Christy, Bing Crosby, Deanna Durbin, Ella Fitzgerald, Judy Garland, Adelaide Hall, Billie Holiday, Bill Kenny, Peggy Lee, Carmen Miranda, Nina Simone, and Dinah Washington.

heading: Births
txt: Carl Orff, German composer and educator (d. 1982)

entities.title: Carl Orff
entities.description: Carl Orff was a German composer and music educator, best known for his cantata Carmina Burana (1937). The concepts of his Schulwerk were influential for children's music education.

heading: Births
txt: Thérèse Casgrain, Canadian politician (d. 1981)

entities.title: Thérèse Casgrain
entities.description: Thérèse Casgrain, LL.D. was a French Canadian feminist, reformer, politician and senator. She was a leader in the fight for women's right to vote in the province of Quebec, as well as the first woman to lead a political party in Canada. In her later life she opposed nuclear weapons and was a consumer activist. A strong federalist, one of her last political actions, at age 83, was to intervene on t

heading: Births
txt: Legs Diamond, American gangster (d. 1931)

entities.title: Legs Diamond
entities.description: Jack "Legs" Diamond, also known as Gentleman Jack, was an Irish American gangster in Philadelphia and New York City during the Prohibition era. A bootlegger and close associate of gambler Arnold Rothstein, Diamond survived a number of attempts on his life between 1916 and 1931, causing him to be known as the "clay pigeon of the underworld". In 1930, Diamond's nemesis Dutch Schultz remarked to his

heading: Births
txt: Karl Plagge, German general and engineer (d. 1957)

txt: Renée Björling, Swedish actress (d. 1975)

entities.title: Renée Björling
entities.description: Renée Björling was a Swedish film actress. She was born in Lovö, Sweden and died in Täby.

heading: Births
txt: John Gilbert, American actor, director, and screenwriter (d. 1936)

entities.title: John Gilbert (actor)
entities.description: John Gilbert was an American actor, screenwriter and director. He rose to fame during the silent film era and became a popular leading man known as "The Great Lover". His legendary breakthrough came in 1925 with his starring roles in The Merry Widow and The Big Parade. At the height of his career, Gilbert rivaled Rudolph Valentino as a box office draw.

txt: Sampson Sievers, Russian monk and mystic (d. 1979)

txt: Kurt Alder, German chemist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (d. 1958)

entities.title: Kurt Alder
entities.description: Kurt Alder was a German chemist and Nobel laureate.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry is awarded annually by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences to scientists in the various fields of chemistry. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895, awarded for outstanding contributions in chemistry, physics, literature, peace, and physiology or medicine. This award is administered by the Nobel Foundation, and awarded by t

heading: Births
txt: Nicolás Guillén, Cuban poet, journalist, and activist (d. 1989)

txt: Werner Best, German SS officer and jurist (d. 1989)

entities.title: Werner Best
entities.description: Karl Rudolf Werner Best was a German Nazi, jurist, police chief, SS-Obergruppenführer and Nazi Party leader and theoretician from Darmstadt, Hesse. He was the first chief of Department 1 of the Gestapo, Nazi Germany's secret police, and initiated a registry of all Jews in Germany. As a deputy of SS-Obergruppenführer Reinhard Heydrich, he organized the World War II SS-Einsatzgruppen paramilitary de

entities.title: SS
entities.description: The Schutzstaffel was a major paramilitary organization under Adolf Hitler and the Nazi Party in Nazi Germany, and later throughout German-occupied Europe during World War II. It began with a small guard unit known as the Saal-Schutz made up of party volunteers to provide security for party meetings in Munich. In 1925, Heinrich Himmler joined the unit, which had by then been reformed and given its

heading: Births
txt: John Wyndham, English soldier and author (d. 1969)

heading: Births
txt: Lili Damita, French-American actress (d. 1994)

entities.title: Lili Damita
entities.description: Lili Damita was a French-American actress and singer who appeared in 33 films between 1922 and 1937.

heading: Births
txt: Mildred Benson, American journalist and author (d. 2002)

entities.title: Mildred Benson
entities.description: Mildred Augustine Wirt Benson was an American journalist and author of children's books. She wrote some of the earliest Nancy Drew mysteries and created the detective's adventurous personality. Benson wrote under the Stratemeyer Syndicate pen name, Carolyn Keene, from 1929 to 1947 and contributed to 23 of the first 30 Nancy Drew mysteries, which were bestsellers.

heading: Births
txt: Blind Boy Fuller, American singer and guitarist (d. 1941)

entities.title: Blind Boy Fuller
entities.description: Blind Boy Fuller was an American blues guitarist and singer. Fuller was one of the most popular of the recorded Piedmont blues artists with rural African Americans along with Blind Blake, Josh White, and Buddy Moss.

heading: Births
txt: Donald Sinclair, English lieutenant and businessman (d. 1981)

entities.title: Donald Sinclair (hotel owner)
entities.description: Donald William Sinclair was the co-proprietor of the Gleneagles Hotel in Torquay, England. He helped manage the hotel after an extensive career as an officer in the Merchant Navy and the Royal Navy. During the Second World War, Sinclair twice survived the sinking of the ships on which he was serving.

heading: Births
txt: Terry-Thomas, English comedian and character actor (d. 1990)

entities.title: Terry-Thomas
entities.description: Terry-Thomas was an English comedian and character actor who became known to a worldwide audience through his films during the 1950s and 1960s. He often portrayed disreputable members of the upper classes, especially cads, toffs and bounders, using his distinctive voice; his costume and props tended to include a monocle, waistcoat and cigarette holder. heading: Births
txt: Cootie Williams, American trumpeter and bandleader (d. 1985)

heading: Births
txt: Salvador Espriu, Spanish author, poet, and playwright (d. 1985)

entities.title: Salvador Espriu
entities.description: Salvador Espriu i Castelló was a Catalan poet who wrote most of his works in Catalan.

heading: Births
txt: Joe Shuster, Canadian-American illustrator, co-created Superman (d. 1992)

entities.title: Joe Shuster
entities.description: Joseph Shuster was a Canadian-American comic book artist best known for co-creating the DC Comics character Superman, with writer Jerry Siegel, in Action Comics #1.

entities.title: Superman
entities.description: Superman is a fictional superhero who first appeared in American comic books published by DC Comics. The character was created by writer Jerry Siegel and artist Joe Shuster, and first appeared in the comic book Action Comics #1. Superman has been adapted to a number of other media which includes radio serials, novels, movies, television shows and theatre.

entities.title: Hugh Alexander (baseball)
entities.description: Hugh Alexander was an American professional baseball player and scout. He was an outfielder during his brief playing career, but after he suffered a career-ending injury at the age of 20 he became one of baseball's most celebrated scouts.

txt: Reg Smythe, English cartoonist (d. 1998)

entities.description: Harold Edward James Aldridge was an Australian-British writer and journalist. His World War II despatches were published worldwide and he was the author of over 30 books, both fiction and non-fiction works, including war and adventure novels and books for children.

entities.title: David Brinkley
entities.description: David McClure Brinkley was an American newscaster for NBC and ABC in a career lasting from 1943 to 1997.

heading: Births
txt: Cyril Grant, English footballer (d. 2002)

heading: Births
txt: Harvey Ball, American illustrator, created the Smiley (d. 2001)

entities.title: Harvey Ball
entities.description: Harvey Ross Ball was an American commercial artist. He is recognized as the designer of a popular smiley graphic picture, which became an enduring and notable international icon. He never applied for a trademark for the iconic smiley image and only earned $45 for his efforts. Ball later founded the World Smile Foundation in 1999, a non-profit charitable trust that supports children’s causes.

entities.title: Smiley
entities.description: A smiley, sometimes referred to as a smiley face, is a basic ideogram that represents a smiling face. txt: Imelda May, Irish singer-songwriter, musician, and producer

entities.title: Imelda May
entities.description: Imelda Mary Higham, professionally known as Imelda May, is an Irish singer, songwriter and multi-instrumentalist. Although known primarily as a singer, she also plays the bodhrán, guitar, bass guitar and tambourine. Described as "a unique vocal talent," May is known for her musical style of rockabilly revival and has also been compared to female jazz musicians such as Billie Holiday.

heading: Births
txt: April Ivy, Portuguese composer and singer

entities.title: April Ivy
entities.description: Mariana Barreiros Dos Santos Gonçalves, better known as April Ivy, is a Portuguese singer/songwriter. She signed with Universal Music France in 2016 where she climbed onto number 1 on the Portuguese iTunes chart with her single "Be Ok", and has now released as a compilation of all her singles. Her debut album is called game.of.love. She’s currently releasing her new music as an independent artist.

She played the lead role of CJ Martin on the Nickelodeon television series 100 Things to Do Before High School. In film, she has played Izabella in Transformers: The Last Knight (2017), Lizzy in Instant Family (2018), and Isabel in Sicario: Day of the Soldado (2018). In 2019, she starred as the titular charac

heading: Deaths
txt: Hadrian, Roman emperor (b. 76)

entities.title: Hadrian
entities.description: Hadrian was Roman emperor from 117 to 138. He was born into a Roman Italo-Hispanic family that settled in Spain from the Italian city of Atri in Picenum. His father was of senatorial rank and was a first cousin of Emperor Trajan. He married Trajan's grand-niece Vibia Sabina early in his career, before Trajan became emperor and possibly at the behest of Trajan's wife Pompeia Plotina. Plotina and Tr

heading: Deaths

entities.description: Soga no Iruka  was the son of Soga no Emishi, a statesman in the Asuka Period of Japan.

heading: Deaths
txt: Tai Zong, Chinese emperor (b. 598)

entities.title: Emperor Taizong of Tang
entities.description: Emperor Taizong of Tang, previously Prince of Qin, personal name Li Shimin, was the second emperor of the Tang dynasty of China, ruling from 626 to 649. He is traditionally regarded as a co-founder of the dynasty for his role in encouraging Li Yuan, his father, to rebel against the Sui dynasty at Jinyang in 617. Taizong subsequently played a pivotal role in defeating several of the dynasty's most

heading: Deaths
txt: Amalberga of Temse, Frankish noblewoman

entities.title: Amalberga of Temse
entities.description: Amalberga of Temse was a Lotharingian noblewoman from the Frankish royal house of the Pippinids who is celebrated as a saint in the Roman Catholic Church and the Eastern Orthodox Church. She is especially venerated in Temse, Ghent, Munsterbilzen and other parts of Flanders. She received the veil from Saint Willibrord of Echternach.

heading: Deaths

entities.title: Pope Benedict VII
entities.description: Pope Benedict VII was the bishop of Rome and ruler of the Papal States from October 974 to his death.

entities.title: Catholic Church
entities.description: The Catholic Church, often referred to as the Roman Catholic Church, is the largest Christian church, with approximately 1.3 billion baptised Catholics worldwide as of 2019. As the world's oldest and largest continuously functioning international institution, it has played a prominent role in the history and development of Western civilisation. The church consists of 24 particular churches and alm

heading: Deaths
txt: Leopold I, margrave of Austria

entities.title: Leopold I, Margrave of Austria
entities.description: Leopold I, known as the Illustrious, a member of the House of Babenberg, was Margrave of Austria from 976 until his death. He was the first margrave of the Babenberg dynasty which ruled the March and Duchy of Austria until its extinction in 1246.

heading: Deaths
txt: Canute IV, king of Denmark (b. 1043)

entities.title: Canute IV of Denmark
entities.description: Canute IV, later known as Canute the Holy or Saint Canute, was King of Denmark from 1080 until 1086. Canute was an ambitious king who sought to strengthen the Danish monarchy, devotedly supported the Roman Catholic Church, and had designs on the English throne. Slain by rebels in 1086, he was the first Danish king to be canonized. He was recognized by the Roman Catholic Church as patron saint of D

heading: Deaths
txt: Eric I, king of Denmark (b. 1060)

entities.title: Eric I of Denmark
entities.description: Eric I, also known as Eric the Good, was King of Denmark following his brother Olaf I Hunger in 1095. He was a son of Sweyn II. His mother's identity is unknown. He married Boedil Thurgotsdatter.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ladislaus IV, king of Hungary (b. 1262)

entities.title: Ladislaus IV of Hungary
entities.description: Ladislaus IV, also known as Ladislas the Cuman, was king of Hungary and Croatia from 1272 to 1290. His mother, Elizabeth, was the daughter of a chieftain from the pagan Cumans who had settled in Hungary. At the age of seven, he married Elisabeth, a daughter of King Charles I of Sicily. Ladislaus was only 10 when a rebellious lord, Joachim Gutkeled, kidnapped and imprisoned him.

heading: Deaths
txt: Humphrey Stafford, 1st Duke of Buckingham, English commander and politician, Lord High Constable of England (b. 1402)

entities.title: Humphrey Stafford, 1st Duke of Buckingham
entities.description: Humphrey Stafford, 1st Duke of Buckingham, 6th Earl of Stafford, of Stafford Castle in Staffordshire, was an English nobleman and a military commander in the Hundred Years' War and the Wars of the Roses. Through his mother he had royal descent from King Edward III, his great-grandfather, and from his father, he inherited, at an early age, the earldom of Stafford. By his marriage to a daughter of R

entities.title: Lord High Constable of England
entities.description: The Lord High Constable of England is the seventh of the Great Officers of State, ranking beneath the Lord Great Chamberlain and above the Earl Marshal. His office is now called out of abeyance only for coronations. The Lord High Constable was originally the commander of the royal armies and the Master of the Horse. He was also, in conjunction with the Earl Marshal, president of the court of chiva

heading: Deaths
txt: John Talbot, 2nd Earl of Shrewsbury, English nobleman (b. c. 1413)

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas, king of Bosnia (b. 1411)

entities.title: Stephen Thomas of Bosnia
entities.description: Stephen Thomas, a member of the House of Kotromanić, reigned from 1443 until his death as the penultimate King of Bosnia.

heading: Deaths
txt: James II, king of Cyprus

entities.title: James II of Cyprus
entities.description: James II was the penultimate King of Cyprus, reigning from 1463 until his death.

heading: Deaths
txt: René of Anjou, French nobleman (b. 1400)

entities.title: René of Anjou
entities.description: René of Anjou was Duke of Anjou and Count of Provence from 1434 to 1480, who also reigned as King of Naples as René I from 1435 to 1442. Having spent his last years in Aix-en-Provence, he is known in France as the Good King René.

heading: Deaths
txt: Catherine Cornaro, queen of Cyprus (b. 1454)

entities.title: Catherine Cornaro
entities.description: Catherine Cornaro was the last monarch of the Kingdom of Cyprus. She was queen consort of Cyprus by marriage to James II of Cyprus, regent of Cyprus during the minority of her son James III of Cyprus in 1473–1474, and finally queen regnant of Cyprus. She reigned from 26 August 1474 to 26 February 1489 and was declared a "Daughter of Saint Mark" in order that the Republic of Venice could claim cont

heading: Deaths
txt: Eleonora di Garzia di Toledo, Italian noble (b. 1553)

entities.title: Eleonora di Garzia di Toledo
entities.description: Eleonora di Garzia di Toledo or Leonor Álvarez de Toledo Osorio, more often known as "Leonora" or "Dianora", was the daughter of García Álvarez de Toledo, 4th Marquis of Villafranca, Duke of Fernandina. Leonora was born in Florence, where she was brought up by Cosimo I de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany and his wife Eleanor of Toledo, her aunt and namesake. Betrothed to their son Pietro at the age

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry II, king of France (b. 1519)

entities.title: Henry II of France
entities.description: Henry II was King of France from 31 March 1547 until his death in 1559. The second son of Francis I, he became Dauphin of France upon the death of his elder brother Francis III, Duke of Brittany, in 1536.

heading: Deaths
txt: William I, Dutch nobleman (b. 1533)

entities.title: William I of Orange
entities.description: William the Silent, also known as William the Taciturn, or William of Orange, was the main leader of the Dutch Revolt against the Spanish Habsburgs that set off the Eighty Years' War (1568–1648) and resulted in the formal independence of the United Provinces in 1581. Born into the House of Nassau, he became Prince of Orange in 1544 and is thereby the founder of the Orange-Nassau branch and the anc

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles II, archduke of Austria (b. 1540)

entities.title: Charles II, Archduke of Austria
entities.description: Charles II Francis of Austria was an Archduke of Austria and ruler of Inner Austria from 1564. He was a member of the House of Habsburg.

heading: Deaths
txt: Paolo Bellasio, Italian organist and composer (b. 1554)

entities.title: Paolo Bellasio
entities.description: Paolo Bellasio was an Italian composer and organist of the late Renaissance. He is generally considered to be a member of the Roman School, though unusually for the group he seems to have written only madrigals.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joan Terès i Borrull, Spanish archbishop and academic (b. 1538)

entities.title: Joan Terès i Borrull
entities.description: Joan Terès i Borrull was presbyter of Vic, auxiliary bishop of Morocco (1575–1579), bishop of Elne (1579–1586) and of Tortosa (1586–1587), and archbishop of Tarragona (1587–1603). He was viceroy of Catalonia (1602–1603) and councillor of King Philip III of Spain.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Bonaventure de Longueval, French commander (b. 1571)

entities.title: Charles Bonaventure de Longueval, Count of Bucquoy
entities.description: Charles Bonaventure de Longueval, Count of Bucquoy was a military commander who fought for the Spanish Netherlands during the Eighty Years' War and for the Holy Roman Empire during the Thirty Years' War.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gabriel Naudé, French librarian and scholar (b. 1600)

entities.title: Gabriel Naudé
entities.description: Gabriel Naudé was a French librarian and scholar. He was a prolific writer who produced works on many subjects including politics, religion, history and the supernatural. An influential work on library science was the 1627 book Advice on Establishing a Library. Naudé was later able to put into practice all the ideas he put forth in Advice, when he was given the opportunity to build and maintain th

heading: Deaths
txt: Louis Moréri, French priest and scholar (b. 1643)

entities.title: Louis Moréri
entities.description: Louis Moréri was a French priest and encyclopedist.

heading: Deaths

entities.title: François Eudes de Mézeray
entities.description: François Eudes de Mézeray was a French historian.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Fell, English bishop and academic (b. 1625)

entities.title: John Fell (bishop)
entities.description: John Fell was an English churchman and influential academic. He served as Dean of Christ Church, Oxford, and later concomitantly as Bishop of Oxford.

heading: Deaths
txt: Richard Peters, English lawyer and minister (b. 1704)

entities.title: Richard Peters (priest)
entities.description: Richard Peters, born in Liverpool, became an attorney, Anglican minister, and civil servant. In 1735 he emigrated to Pennsylvania, where he served in numerous posts for the Penn family, including on the Governor's Council from 1749 to 1775, and eventually became rector of Christ Church in Philadelphia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gaspard de Bernard de Marigny, French general (b. 1754)

entities.title: Gaspard de Bernard de Marigny
entities.description: Gaspard Augustin René Bernard de Marigny was a French officer and Vendéen general.

heading: Deaths
txt: George Stubbs, English painter and academic (b. 1724)

entities.title: George Stubbs
entities.description: George Stubbs was an English painter, best known for his paintings of horses. Self-trained, Stubbs learnt his skills independently from other great artists of the eighteenth century such as Reynolds or Gainsborough. Stubbs' output includes history paintings, but his greatest skill was in painting animals, perhaps influenced by his love and study of anatomy. His most famous painting, Whistlejacket,

heading: Deaths
txt: Louis Daguerre, French photographer and physicist, invented the daguerreotype (b. 1787)

entities.title: Louis Daguerre
entities.description: Louis-Jacques-Mandé Daguerre, better known as Louis Daguerre, was a French artist and photographer, recognized for his invention of the daguerreotype process of photography. He became known as one of the fathers of photography. Though he is most famous for his contributions to photography, he was also an accomplished painter and a developer of the diorama theatre.

entities.title: Daguerreotype
entities.description: The daguerreotype was the first publicly available photographic process—widely used during the 1840s and 1850s. "Daguerreotype" also refers to the images created through this process.

heading: Deaths
txt: Clement Clarke Moore, American author and educator (b. 1779)

entities.title: Clement Clarke Moore
entities.description: Clement Clarke Moore was a writer and American Professor of Oriental and Greek Literature, as well as Divinity and Biblical Learning, at the General Theological Seminary of the Protestant Episcopal Church, in New York City. The seminary was developed on land donated by Moore and it continues on this site at Ninth Avenue between 20th and 21st streets, in an area known as Chelsea Square. Moore's con

heading: Deaths
txt: Georg Hermann Nicolai, German architect and academic (b. 1812)

entities.title: Georg Hermann Nicolai
entities.description: Georg Hermann Nicolai was a German architect and educator, Professor of Architecture at the Royal Academy of Fine Arts on the Brühl Terrace in Dresden from 1850 until his death.

heading: Deaths
txt: Paul Morphy, American chess player (b. 1837)

entities.title: Paul Morphy
entities.description: Paul Charles Morphy was an American chess player. He is considered to have been the greatest chess master of his era and the unofficial second World Chess Champion (1858–1860). A chess prodigy, he was called "The Pride and Sorrow of Chess" because he had a brilliant chess career but retired from the game while still young. Bobby Fischer and Viswanathan Anand ranked Morphy among the ten greatest ch

heading: Deaths
txt: Phoebe Knapp, American organist and composer (b. 1839)

entities.title: Phoebe Knapp
entities.description: Phoebe Palmer Knapp was an American composer of music for hymns and an organist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hendrik Willem Mesdag, Dutch painter (b. 1831)

entities.title: Hendrik Willem Mesdag
entities.description: Hendrik Willem Mesdag was a Dutch marine painter.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Fisher, 1st Baron Fisher, British admiral (b. 1841)

entities.title: John Fisher, 1st Baron Fisher
entities.description: John Arbuthnot Fisher, 1st Baron Fisher,, commonly known as Jacky or Jackie Fisher, was a British Admiral of the Fleet known for his efforts at naval reform. He had a huge influence on the Royal Navy in a career spanning more than 60 years, starting in a navy of wooden sailing ships armed with muzzle-loading cannon and ending in one of steel-hulled battlecruisers, submarines and the first aircraft

heading: Deaths
txt: Ève Lavallière, French actress (b. 1866)

entities.title: Ève Lavallière
entities.description: Ève Lavallière was a French stage actress and later a noteworthy Catholic penitent and member of the Secular Franciscan Order.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jelly Roll Morton, American pianist, composer, and bandleader (b. 1890)

entities.title: Jelly Roll Morton
entities.description: Ferdinand Joseph LaMothe, known professionally as Jelly Roll Morton, was an American ragtime and jazz pianist, bandleader, and composer. Morton was jazz's first arranger, proving that a genre rooted in improvisation could retain its essential characteristics when notated. His composition "Jelly Roll Blues", published in 1915, was one of the first published jazz compositions. Morton also wrote "Kin

heading: Deaths
txt: Huntley Wright, English actor (b. 1868)

heading: Deaths
txt: Richard Maury, American-Argentinian engineer (b. 1882)

entities.title: Richard Maury
entities.description: Richard Fontaine Maury was an American railway engineer and naturalized Argentine. He became known for the project of the Argentine "Ramal C-14" of the Ferrocarril General Manuel Belgrano and the touristic Tren a las Nubes.

heading: Deaths
txt: Rued Langgaard, Danish organist and composer (b. 1893)

entities.title: Rued Langgaard
entities.description: Rued Langgaard was a late-Romantic Danish composer and organist. His then-unconventional music was at odds with that of his Danish contemporaries but was recognized 16 years after his death.

heading: Deaths
txt: Calogero Vizzini, Italian mob boss (b. 1877)

entities.title: Calogero Vizzini
entities.description: Calogero "Don Calò" Vizzini was a historical Sicilian Mafia boss of Villalba in the Province of Caltanissetta, Sicily. Vizzini was considered to be one of the most influential and legendary Mafia bosses of Sicily after World War II until his death in 1954. In the media, he was often depicted as the "boss of bosses" – although such a position does not exist in the loose structure of Cosa Nostra.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joe Giard, American baseball player (b. 1898)

entities.title: Joe Giard
entities.description: Joseph Oscar Giard was an American major league baseball player.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sæbjørn Buttedahl, Norwegian actor and sculptor (b. 1876)

entities.title: Sæbjørn Buttedahl
entities.description: Sæbjørn Buttedahl was a Norwegian stage and film actor who later found prominence as a sculptor.

heading: Deaths
txt: Yehuda Leib Maimon, Israeli rabbi and politician (b. 1875)

entities.title: Yehuda Leib Maimon
entities.description: Yehuda Leib Maimon was an Israeli rabbi, politician and leader of the Religious Zionist movement. He was Israel's first Minister of Religions.

heading: Deaths
txt: Teddy Wakelam, English rugby player and sportscaster (b. 1893)

entities.title: Teddy Wakelam
entities.description: Lieutenant-Colonel Henry Blythe Thornhill Wakelam, known as Teddy Wakelam, was an English sports broadcaster and rugby union player who captained Harlequin F.C..

heading: Deaths
txt: Bjarni Benediktsson, Icelandic academic and politician, 13th Prime Minister of Iceland (b. 1908)

entities.title: Bjarni Benediktsson (born 1908)
entities.description: Bjarni Benediktsson was an Icelandic politician of the Independence Party who served as Prime Minister of Iceland from 1963 to 1970. His father, Benedikt Sveinsson (1877–1954), was a leader in the independence movement in Iceland and a member of the Althingi from 1908 to 1931.

entities.title: Prime Minister of Iceland
entities.description: The prime minister of Iceland is Iceland's head of government. The prime minister is appointed formally by the president and exercises executive authority along with the cabinet subject to parliamentary support.

heading: Deaths
txt: Laurent Dauthuille, French boxer (b. 1924)

entities.title: Laurent Dauthuille
entities.description: Laurent Dauthuille was a French boxer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lovie Austin, American pianist, composer, and bandleader (b. 1887)

entities.title: Lovie Austin
entities.description: Cora "Lovie" Austin was an American Chicago bandleader, session musician, composer, singer, and arranger during the 1920s classic blues era. She and Lil Hardin Armstrong are often ranked as two of the best female jazz blues piano players of the period.

heading: Deaths
txt: John D. Rockefeller III, American businessman and philanthropist, founded the Asia Society (b. 1906)

entities.title: John D. Rockefeller III
entities.description: John Davison Rockefeller III was an American philanthropist and the eldest son of John D. Rockefeller Jr. and Abby Aldrich Rockefeller. He was engaged in a wide range of philanthropic projects, many of which his family had launched, as well as supporting organizations related to East Asian affairs. Rockefeller was also a major supporter of the Population Council, and the committee that created the

entities.title: Asia Society
entities.description: The Asia Society is a non-profit organization that focuses on educating the world about Asia. It has several centers in the United States and around the world. These centers are overseen by the Society's headquarters in New York City, which includes a museum that exhibits the Rockefeller collection of Asian art and rotating exhibits with pieces from many countries in Asia and Oceania.

heading: Deaths
txt: Arthur Fiedler, American conductor (b. 1894)

entities.title: Arthur Fiedler
entities.description: Arthur Fiedler was an American conductor known for his association with the Boston Symphony and Boston Pops orchestras. With a combination of musicianship and showmanship, he made the Boston Pops one of the best-known orchestras in the United States. Fiedler was sometimes criticized for over-popularizing music, particularly when adapting popular songs or editing portions of the classical repertoir

heading: Deaths
txt: Joseph Krumgold, American author and screenwriter (b. 1908)

entities.title: Joseph Krumgold
entities.description: Joseph Quincy Krumgold was an American writer of books and screenplays. He was the first person to win two annual Newbery Medals for the most distinguished new American children's book.

heading: Deaths
txt: Fernando Pereira, Dutch photographer (b. 1950)

entities.title: Fernando Pereira
entities.description: Fernando Pereira was a freelance Portuguese-Dutch photographer, who drowned when French intelligence (DGSE) detonated a bomb and sank the Rainbow Warrior, owned by the environmental organisation Greenpeace on 10 July 1985.

heading: Deaths
txt: Tadeusz Piotrowski, Polish mountaineer and author (b. 1940)

entities.title: Tadeusz Piotrowski (mountaineer)
entities.description: Tadeusz Piotrowski was a Polish mountaineer and author of several books related to the subject. He has been referred to as "perhaps the finest winter mountaineer of his day".

heading: Deaths
txt: John Hammond, American record producer, critic, and activist (b. 1910)

entities.title: John Hammond (producer)
entities.description: John Henry Hammond II was an American record producer, civil rights activist, and music critic from the 1930s to the early 1980s. In his service as a talent scout, Hammond became one of the most influential figures in 20th-century popular music. He is the father of famous blues musician John P. Hammond.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mel Blanc, American voice actor (b. 1908)

entities.title: Mel Blanc
entities.description: Mel Blanc was an American voice actor, comedian, and radio personality. After beginning his over-60-year career performing in radio, he became known for his work in animation as the voices of Bugs Bunny, Daffy Duck, Porky Pig, and most of the other characters from the Looney Tunes and Merrie Melodies theatrical cartoons during the golden age of American animation.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ruth Krauss, American author and poet (b. 1901)

entities.title: Ruth Krauss
entities.description: Ruth Ida Krauss was an American writer of children's books, including The Carrot Seed, and of theatrical poems for adult readers. Many of her books are still in print.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mehmet Ali Aybar, Turkish lawyer and politician (b. 1908)

entities.title: Mehmet Ali Aybar
entities.description: Mehmet Ali Aybar was a lawyer, member of the Turkish parliament, the second president of the Workers Party of Turkey, the founder and President of the Socialist Revolution Party, and a member of the Russell Tribunal against the war crimes of the United States in Vietnam.

heading: Deaths
txt: Eno Raud, Estonian author (b. 1928)

entities.title: Eno Raud
entities.description: Eno Raud was an Estonian children's writer. His works are considered classics in Estonia as well as in the other former Soviet countries. Raud was included in International Board on Books for Young People (IBBY) Honour List in 1974.

heading: Deaths
txt: Vakkom Majeed, Indian journalist and politician (b. 1909)

entities.title: Vakkom Majeed
entities.description: Vakkom Majeed was an Indian freedom fighter, politician and a former member of the Travancore-Cochin State Assembly. He was born into one of the most prominent aristocratic Muslim families in Travancore. heading: Deaths
txt: Winston Graham, English author (b. 1908)

entities.title: Winston Graham
entities.description: Winston Mawdsley Graham OBE, born Winston Grime, was an English novelist best known for the Poldark series of historical novels set in Cornwall, though he also wrote numerous other works, including contemporary thrillers, period novels, short stories, non-fiction and plays. Winston Graham was the author's pseudonym until he changed his name by deed poll from Grime to Graham on 7 May 1947.

entities.title: Attorney General for England and Wales
entities.description: Her Majesty's Attorney General for England and Wales, usually known as the Attorney General, is one of the Law Officers of the Crown. The Attorney General serves as the principal legal adviser to the Crown and the Government in England and Wales. The Attorney General maintains their own office and currently attends Cabinet. heading: Deaths

entities.title: A. J. Quinnell
entities.description: A. J. Quinnell was the pen name of the English thriller novelist Philip Nicholson. He is best known for his novel Man on Fire, which has been adapted to film twice, most recently in 2004 featuring Denzel Washington.

entities.description: Shamil Salmanovich Basayev was a senior leader of the Chechen movement, recognized as a terrorist by Russia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Doug Marlette, American cartoonist and author (b. 1949)

entities.title: Doug Marlette
entities.description: Douglas Nigel Marlette was a Pulitzer Prize-winning American editorial cartoonist who, at the time of his death, had also published two novels and was "finding his voice in writing long-length fiction." His popular comic strip Kudzu, distributed by Tribune Media Services from 1981 to 2007, was adapted into a musical comedy.

entities.title: Hiroaki Aoki
entities.description: Hiroaki Aoki , best known as Rocky Aoki, was a Japanese-American amateur wrestler and restaurateur who founded the popular Japanese cuisine restaurant chain Benihana.

entities.title: Benihana
entities.description: Benihana Inc.  is an American restaurant company based in Aventura, Florida. It owns or franchises 116 Japanese cuisine restaurants around the world, including its flagship Benihana Teppanyaki brand, as well as the Haru and RA Sushi restaurants. He is widely regarded as the country's King of Comedy for his comedic talent embodied by his long roster of works on stage, radio, television and movies.

heading: Deaths
txt: Roger Rees, Welsh-American actor and director (b. 1944)

entities.title: Roger Rees
entities.description: Roger Rees was a Welsh actor and director, widely known for his stage work. He won an Olivier Award and a Tony Award for his performance as the lead in The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby. He also received Obie Awards for his role in The End of the Day and as co-director of Peter and the Starcatcher. Rees was posthumously inducted into the American Theater Hall of Fame in November 2015.

entities.description: Katharina Focke was a German politician of the Social Democratic Party of Germany (SPD). She served as Federal Minister of Family Affairs, Senior Citizens, Women and Youth from 1972 to 1976.

entities.description: Henry Morgenthau III was an American author and television producer, and scion of the famous Morgenthau dynasty and member of the Lehman family.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lara van Ruijven, Dutch short track speed skater (b. 1992)

entities.title: Lara van Ruijven
entities.description: Lara Victoria van Ruijven was a Dutch short track speed skater. At the 2018 Winter Olympics, she was part of the Dutch 3000 metres relay team that won a bronze medal. She won gold at the World Championships one year later. By doing so, she became the first Dutch woman to win a world short track title at an individual event.
